div.p: The godly saiyngs of the old auncient faithful fathers / vpon the Sacrament of the the bodye and bloude of Chryste. Newlye compyled and translated oute of Latin intoo English. By Ihon Veron Senonoys.

q.p: As often as ye eate of thys breade, and drynke of thys cuppe, ye shal shew furth the lordes death tyll he come.

div.head: ¶ The names and times of ye holy doctors whiche we do folow in thys lyttle treatye.
div.p: AVgustyne was borne in Carthage, & was bisshoppe of Hippone, a Citie in Aphrica. He dyed in the yere of our Lorde. C C C C. xxx. when he was. lx xvi. yeres of age.
¶ Ambrose was Bisshoppe of Milane, in Lombardie, being a Romaine borne, he did florisshe vnder Theodosius the Emperour, in the yere of our Lorde. C C C. xxx.
¶ Athanasius the .xix. bisshop of Alexandria, died in the yeare of our Lorde. C C C. lxxix.

¶ Bede being Prieste of thys countrey of England, then called Britaine, died in the yere of
our lorde. D. C C. xxxii.
¶ Barnard was in the yeare of our Lord. M. C. xl.
¶ Chrisostome beinge bisshop of Constantinople, dyed in the yere of our lorde. C C C C. xi.

¶ Fulgentius was bysshop of Ruspa, in Aphrike. Thys man did florish in all godly learning at ye time, yt Trasmundus king of ye Wandallians, did persecute the faithfull churche of Christe, in the yere of our Lorde. D.
¶ Gelasius, fyrst of that name was bisshop of Rome .iiii. yeres and died in the yere of our lord C C C C. xcvi.
¶ Hierome beinge borne in a towne of Italie, called Studō, dyed in the yere of our Lorde. C C C C. xxii.
¶ Origene being born in Alexandria, did florysshe in the yere of our lorde. C C. lxi.
¶ Prosper beinge of ye nation of Aquitaine, was Bisshoppe of Reginum, and did florishe in ye yere of our lord. C C C C. lx
¶ Tertullian was of the citie of Carthage, in Aphrica, & did florish in the yere of our lord C C.

div.head: ¶ The authour to the Christian readers.
div.l: ¶ Because I was in Fraunce, which is so wyde,
Borne & brought vp, & not in yt English
Sins my birthes dai, as other writers be
Learned and taught: do I earnestlye,
Now you al that in England do dwell,
And professe Christ, yt euer springing wel
Desyre and pray, to take in good worth,
That I haue here wrought & set furthe.

div.head: To the right worshypfull, Syr Ihon Yorke, Knight, treasurer of the Kinges Maiesties Mint in Southwarke, master of all ye Kinges wooddes, on this syde Trente, and Shriue of the noble citie of London, Ihon Peron wissheth healthe of soule and bodye, with encrease of dyuyne knowledge and vnderstandynge, from the heauenlye father, through our lord and Sauyoure Iesus Christe.
div.p:
MEN are wonte, for the most parte, either of superstition, to attrybute to muche to the holy sacramentes, or of a lyghtnes and inconstancie, to attribute to little vntoo them. Whyche thing we may easly se in the historyes of the olde auncyent Iewes, which had alwayes
for an high sacramente, the Arke of the lordes couenaunt, that with plain wordes, is called the lord of hostes. For in the second boke of the kinges, and .vi. ii. kin .vi. cha. Cha. the scripture doth testifye and saye: Dauid rising vp, went with all hys people, to fetche the Arke of God, wherupon the name of the lorde god of hostes. whiche sitteth vpon Cherubin, is called vpon. And this after yt phrase of the Hebrues, is as muche to say, as vnto whom a name is geuen, that it should be called Iehouah, or the lord of hostes sytting vpon Cherubin: Thys verely was a great mistery, and an high sacrament. But when the Israelites dydde attrybute to muche vntoo it, they were ouerthrowen, and subdued wt the warres of Philistyns, and the Arke also was taken and caried away into captyuitie. For so we do reade in the holy Bible, that Israel was ouerthrowen before the Philystins, iiii. M. men of them beyng slayne. And when ye people of Israel did return into the Campe, the elders and seniours of Israel, dyd say: Why hath the lord ouerthrowen vs this day before the Philistines?
We wyll bringe from Silo, the i Sam. iiii. cha Arke of the lordes couenaunt, yt it maye be in the middest of vs, and saue vs from the handes of our enemyes. The people therfore dyd send to Silo, and did bring from thence the Arke of the lorde of hostes, sytting vpon Cherubin. And when the Arke of the couenaunt was come in to the Campe, all Israel gaue so great a shoute, that the earth did quake. Which crie and noyse, when ye Philistines herd and had alsoo knowledge, that the Arke of the lorde was come into the Campe, they were sore afrayde, sayinge: God is come into the Campe. Wo be vntoo vs. Who shall delyuer vs from the hand of these straunge goddes. These be the god des that dyd smyte Egipt with somany plagues, yet notwythstandynge, be of a good chere, and fyght lyke men. So the Philistines did strike battaile, and Israel was discomfited, and fled euerye man intoo hys tente, and there was a greate slaughter done. For .xxx. thousande of ye Isralites footemen were killed, yea, and the Arke was taken. Now haue ye herd what the Israelites did attribute vnto ye Arke, and what misfortune both for this
erroure, and alsoo for other synnes, they dyd then suffer and receyue of theyr enemyes. For the Lorde had not gyuen therefore the Arke vnto his people, that they shoulde put theyr truste in it, or beleue that it moughte delyuer and saue theym from the handes of theyr enemyes: but that it shoulde be a sygne and token of the presence and helpe of GOD and was therefore called the Lorde of hostes, because it shoulde be a certayne testymonye and wytnesse of the couenaunte made betwyxt God and the people. For it dyd teffyfye that god would be presente, alwayes fauourable and family are vntoo hys people. In the same Arke, the tables of the couenaunte were contayned and kepte, wherof it dyd get hys name, and was called the Arke of the couenaunte. Whyche when they dydde contrarywyse handle irreuerentlye, hauynge it in lesse estymatyon then they oughte, manye more of them were slayne then when they dydde attrybute too muche vntoo it.

For when the Phylystynes beynge plagued with foul diseases, had brought i. Samuel .v. and .vi. Chap. the Arke agayne, and restored it too the
Israelytes, the people whyche loked in it irreuerently were slayne. For the scripture saythe: The Lorde dyd plague the Bethsemeites, because they had looked in the Arke of the lorde, and he did strike fiftye thousand and thre score and tenne men. For it was forbydden by the lawe (as it is wrytten in the boke of Numery ii. king .vi. cha the forthe Chapiter), that no man shuld searche or loke in the Arke of the lord of hostes, wyth prophane and irreuerente eyes. Wherefore in the exposytyon and ministring of the sacramentes, that onelye whyche is prescribed in the worde of GOD, and the scryptures muste of necessytye be folowed. But nowe let vs cōpare thys worlde wyth those auncyente tymes, and we shall in thys matter fynd theym in all thynges lyke. For thou shalte fynde some whyche attrybute all As if a manne forsaking prodigalitie shuld fal into begetly nigardship or forsakynge vngodlynesse, shulde fal into superstition. maner of thynges too the Sacramentes and agayne there be some other whych doo attrybute nothinge at all vnto them Soo that in thys poynte, that whyche the heathen Poete Flaccus doth wryte proueth moste trewe. Fooles whyles they doo flye from one synne, they doo runne intoo an other contrarye vyce.
For there be many whiche doo adscribe vnto the sacramentes, grace, iustyficatiō health and saluation most seruillye, as. S Angustine doth say, worshipping and venerating the signes, for the thinges, whiche by the signes are signified. Such mē haue, and not without sacrilege and spyritual thefte, taken a waie from the faith full, the cuppe of the lordes bloude. Besides that, all men doo knowe that they Ye shall rede in their masse bookes howe thei said Mas for mesel swin for scalde horses. &c. haue abused the lordes supper too heale diseases, to driue away foule spirites, too make fayre weather, and to many other vile and filthy things. And agayne how they vtterly subuerting the outward signes, dyd contende and affirme, that neyther breade nor wyne did remaine, but ye body and bloud of the lord onely. Of the whyche maner of beynge in the Sacramente miraculouslye, they haue dysputed manye thynges, whyche thee apostles neuer knewe, beatynge into the ignoraunte peoples eares, this opynion, that is too saye, that these thinges were offered of the Minyster in theyr Masse, for a satysfaccyon of synne, bothe of the quycke and of the deade, as ye shall see in the decretalles of the hyghe Trynytye
and catholyke fayth, Titu. firmiter credimus. Reade ye boke of yt decretals in the title fyrmiter credimus All men doo alsoo knowe and see what worshyppe hath bene done, and is dayelye done too the mystycall breade of the Lorde: Therefore we do synne no lesse nowe in the Sacramente of the bodye and bloude of Christe, then the auncy auntye dyd synne in the Arke of the Lordes couenaunte. Wherefore the rightuouse Whithe lord dothe at this presente time so horibly plague ye world. lorde, doth wythoute doubte punysshe nowe the worlde, wyth greate & horryble plagues. But nowe that these vngodlye and superstycyons opynyons of the Sacramentes, are oppugned by theym, that haue syncerely preached the iustyfycatyon of faythe, and truth of our Lorde and Sauyoure Iesu Christe, not too thys entente that the Sacramentes shoulde be taken awaye, but that the abuses whyche are aboute theym, superstycyouslye and vngodlye taughte, moughte be cleane abolysshed: lo, by and by spryngeth furthe a newe sorte of people, whyche is fallen intoo Scilla Scilla and C •
ribdis are, i • par •• o • s ro •
kes in the • e • of Scicilia. couetynge too s • onne Caribdis. For saye they: yf the breade be not made and turned into the verye naturall bodye of
Christe, and the wyne intoo hys verye bloude in deede, yea, yf the Sacramente dothe not iustyfye, and brynge grace of it selfe, then it is but bare breade and wyne, nor it skylleth not whether we receiue it or not. Thus these irreuerent persons do atrybute to little vnto the sacramente, as the other dydde attrybute too muche. Wherefore the Mynystre shall What meane the Ministre ought to kepe in ye sacramēt. wyth a wyse and reuerente symplycytie kepe a meane betwene, and reiectynge all those superstycyons and peruerse opynyons, shall teache that twoo thynges in the Sacramente, muste be obserued and consydered, that is too saye, the sygne or earthelye elemente, as breade and wyne, wyth the outewarde mynystratyon, and the thynge whyche by the sygne is represented, as the feloweshyp of Christes churche, the body and bloud of oure Lorde, whyche beyng offered for vs on the crosse, haue recouered vntoo mankynde, the loue and fauour of God in so muche that we be nowe made, thorowe faythe, and the holye spiryte workynge inwardely, the members and heyres of Christe, partakers of euerlastynge lyfe, and of all the benefytes of the onelye
begotten sonne of GOD, oure sauynge healthe. Wherefore it is not ynoughe The bare sygnes onely 〈…〉 ought not 〈…〉 be set furt 〈…〉 to the p 〈…〉
for the Mynyster too preache and set furthe onely the bare sygnes, neglectynge the verye thynge it selfe, as thoughe in the supper of the Lorde, the faythefull shoulde be onelye partakers of breade and wyne, as on the contrarye syde, it is too muche, yf he subuertynge vtterlye the sygnes, dothe teache thee people to venerate and worshyppe the sygnes, for the thynges sygnyfyed by theym: for as the sygnes and tokens oughte circumspectlye too be lymytted, soo we muste haue alwayes a greate respecte too the thynges signyfyed.

In the matter therefore of the Sacramente, The chief and principal thinges in ye matter of ye sacrament must b • earnestlye rehersed and se • before ye eye • of the people. the chyefe and pryncypall thynges therof, must be with a due reuerence set furthe and commended vnto the people, that is too saye: the heauenlye and gratuite benetytes of god, wherwith he doth ouerwhelme vs daily & hourely vsing in the meane season thys outwarde signe, as a certaine token and testimony of hys benefycence and lyberalytye towarde vs. For with the sygnes as wyth vysyble wordes he dothe put befoore
our eyes his benefites, by theym testifyinge and declaryng what he wyll do for vs, if we come vnto him, with adue faith Wherfore it is most necessarye that the What the pastoures are bound to doo when the congregation goeth aboute to celebrate the maundye. pastores do, with the promise of God, & swete sentences of the gospell, styrre vp the fayth of the congregation, whē they go aboute too celebrate this sacramente, for without fayth, the sacramente dothe not profyte, but hurte, not of it selfe, nor through the fault of the faithful minister but throughe the vnfaythfulnes of hym that receiue it. Secondarelye in this supper, yt people must be exhorted to thankfulnes, to laude and prayse God, for the death of our sauyoure Iesu Christe. For Paule sayth: as often as ye eate of thys i. Cor. xi, chap breade, and drynke of this cuppe, shewe furthe the lordes deathe tyll he come.

And for thys cause it was called partely Eucharistia, that is too saye: thankes geuyng. Moreouer they must seriouslye & Why the lordes supper is called Euch aristia. earnestly inculcate and beate into ye heartes of the people, charitie, loue, studye of concord and true innocencie. Vntoo the which thinges, the sacrament if it be duely ministred, dothe in a maner of it selfe, moue and rauysshe all men. For who is
so dul, and without vnderstanding, whiche with this most earnest rehearsall of the benefites of God,, be sydes that, the goodnes of Christe, with a visible appearaunce, signe and token, beynge put before hys eyes, would not be moued too thankefulnes, and mutuall beneficence? Who would not kepe him selfe from the vncleannesse of this worlde, when he seeth and heareth that he is made a membre of Iesu Christe? Againe▪ who would not louingly embrace his Christian brethren, whome he heareth also too be the lymmes of Christ? and to be before god so highly estemed, that he gaue hys onely begotten sonne, too suffer deathe for The Sacramēt is a test •
monial or witnes of mutual faith & loue them? And truely the sacramente is a testimonyal, wherewyth we do testyfye a mutuall faythe betwene vs, and are in a maner confederate together. We do eat all of one breade, and drynke of one cup The bodye and bloude of Christe dothe fede vs all to euerlastyng lyfe. We are all quyckened wyth one spirite. We are al the members of one bodye. Therfore we ought not to disagre amonge our selues, but in Iesu Christ to loue one an other, and to haue al one mynde, and one
fayth. Suche thynges dyd the Apostles intreate vpon, when at anye tyme they dyd minister the sacrament of the bodye and bloud of Christ, without any subtyl Whosoeuer seketh the profyte of Chrystes churche, must ensue & folow ye example of the apostles. disputatyon or reasonyng: Whose example, whosoeuer seketh the profyte of the congregation of god, he shall folowe. Al his intent and endeuoure shall be that ye churche may vnderstand the right vse & institution of this sacrament, and flie frō suche curiouse and vaine questions, onely studying to be, throughe faithe, partakers of the thynge sygnified in the sacrament: That therfore the commune people whyche is vnlearned and knoweth not the tongues, maye the better vnderstande how they ought to receyue thys sacramente, all superstitious peruerse opinions, beyng vtterly extirpated and banisshed from emong the faythful subiectes of this victoriouse and illustre realme I haue at thys presente tyme compyled and translated out of Latin into English the sayinges or opinions of ye auncyente faythfull fathers vpon the sacrament of the boody and bloude of Christe. Wherby al men may learne in what reuerence this sacrament, as a seale of the lyuynge
god, ought to be had, and how the pure The pure and sincer antyquitie did alwais kepe it selfe wt in the inclosures of ye word of god, in the matter of the sacramentes. The antichristes do treade doun the ordinaunces of Christ yt theyr vngodly inuētiōs, & dremes may be set vp. and syncere antiquitie, did kepe it selfe alwayes within the limites and bondes of the sacred scriptures and worde of God beyng in this poynte farre from the impietie and vngodlines of our antichristes whych treading vnder fete, the institutyon and ordynaunce of our sauyour Iesu Christe, the eternall wisedome of the heauenly father, did studye for naughte else but to set vp their owne inuentions and dreames: Wherwith the myndes of many men are so intoxicated and poysoned that it is almoste impossyble to cure and heale them. But I trust that when they haue read this small treatye, whych contaynethe ye myndes of the olde doctours which almoste all, were by and by after the apostles, beyng faythfullye translated for theyr erudition into their mother tongue, they (I meane them which of ignoraunce, and not of malyce do erre, wil be the more ready to forsake theyr blynd error, and to folow & embrace the truthe which our most soueraigne lord, ye King & his honorable counsail hath set furthe. And now because yt I do know yt youre mastership hath bene alwaies a louer of
the truth, and a hater of superstition, and vngodlines euer, as a valiaūt champione of ye lord, wt the sweard of the spirit, whiche is gods word, defending the veritye, to yt vtter ouerthrowing & subuersion of al vngodly errors, which wt the vehemēt & godly spirit of such worshipful men, as your mastership is, being plucked vp by ye rootes, wtout any doubte, the kyngdō Vngodlye errours beynge plucked vp bi the rootes, Antichristes kyngdom can stand no longer. of Antichriste, can not stand no longer, but vanish away as the mist, with ye beames of the bright shining sonne: I haue thought expedient and mete to dedicate this litle work vnto you, in tokē of gratitude & due beneuolence toward your mastership, beseching moste mekely, yt ye of your wont goodnes & facilitie vouchsafe to accept this my rude labour. Herafter wyl I set furth better thinges, in youre masterships name, wt the grace of the lyuing god. Who of his infinite mercifulnes preserue your good mastership, & mi good Lady, your trew louynge spouse & wife, and with his holy spirit so rule and guide your hertes in all your affayres, yt what so euer ye thynke or do, may be to the glorye of god, and saluation of youre soules. Amen.

div.head: ¶ To the christen reader, Ihon Veron wissheth health of bodye and soule, from ye heauenly father, throughe oure lord Iesu Chryste.
div.p:
BEfore yt I procede anye farther, good christē reader, yu shalt vnderstand yt ye holy fathers of yt auncient & primitiue church do in manye places of their writinges, cal this Sacramente the bodye and bloude of oure Lorde and sauyoure Iesu Christe. Whyche thynge verelye they dyd, notte because that they had anye suche carnall opynyon in them as is nowe amonge a greate sorte of learned menne, and greate Clarkes, but because that they beynge thorowelye exercysed in the holye and sacred Scriptures of the Byble, had learned, that the Sacramentes of holye thynges, dyd take the names of the verye selfe same thynges, whereof they are Sacramentes. Augu. ad Bon •
facium. Gene, xvii. cha •

Fyrst, they had read yt ye sacrament of circūsitiō, was called, Pactū siue foedus domini
in the couenaunt of ye lord. Which thing notwtstanding was not ye very couenant in dede: but a signe, tokē, sacrament & memorial of the couenaunt yt was betwene god and Abraham. Again, how yt Iacob did cal the altare that he had builded vnto the lord, Deum Bethel, the God of Bethel, and the place where he wrastled wt Genes. xxviii. Chapi. & xxxii. Chapiter. the aungel. Phuiel seu Phaniel, the face of god. Now (as I suppose) noo man wyll iudge or thinke, except he were without al humain vnderstanding, yt ye same heap of stones which Iacob had gathered together, was ye God of Bethel, or ye place where he wrastled wt the angel, was the face of god in verye dede. But whye are they so called thē? Verelye yt the name itself might put men in remembraune of ye thing yt by thē was signified & betokened Euen as afterwardes, when ye childrē of Israel wer deliuered out of Egipt, ye pascal lambe (which was a sacrament most reuerently kept alwaies emong ye Iues) was called Pesac, id est transitus domini, ye lordes passeouer, that they hearinge this Exod. xi. Cha word, passeouer might immediatly cal in to their remembraunce, the innumerable benefites of their mighty & omnipotent
sauiour. Which passing by throughe the land of their enemies, did slaye al ye firste born of Egipt, & so with a mighty & stretched furth arme, did bring them safe thorow ye red sea, from al misery, wretchednes & thraldom, into a land that floweth with milke & hony, And verelye when ye lambe was once selected, chosen & taken out of ye flocke, and applied to ye holy vse that god, by hys seruaunte Moises, had before theyr deliueraunce out of Egipte instituted and ordeined, it was noo more called a lambe, but ye passeouer of ye lorde Which phrase & maner of speaking, all ye auncyente fathers and prophetes of the old Testament, did vse alwayes in theyr sermons and writynges. And our Lorde Iesus Christ, the euerlastinge wisedome of god the father, did confirme the same, when he did institute and ordaine the sacrament of his death and passyon vntoo vs, callynge the sacramente of his bodye & bloud, by the very name of those most holy and sacred thinges, which by it are signified. That when in the celebratyon of the holy misteries, we doo heare these wordes. This is my bodye, and this is my bloud, Marke well good reader the analogie
of ye old & new sacraments, for he ye saith of ye lamb, This is the passeouer of the lord, which this night shal passe by, doth say also of ye bread, This is my body, which shal be deliuered for you, we by & by put before our eies that most precious body, which so pitiously on yt crosse, was brokē for vs, & also his most holy & sacred blud which wt the handes of ye vngodlye, wasshed for our sinnes, wherfore (as I haue said before of ye lambe) when the bread & wine, is by ye true and faithful ministers preaching & anunciatyng ye lordes death and passion vnto ye christen people, applied vnto yt thing which our sauioure hath ordeyned, it is no lenger called bread and wine (though in some places of ye scriptures we fynd that both Luke & Paule do cal it bread, & the cup) but the bodye and bloud of our lord: and for this cause doth S. Paul say: he yt eateth of thys bread, & drinketh of this cup vnworthely, shal be gylty of the body & bloud of ye lord. As if he should say: he yt regardeth not the purpose, for ye which, Christ did institute this sacramente, which commeth not vnto it with a spiritual hunger, to eate throughe faith his very body, and with a spirituall
thirst, to drinke through faith, hys verye bloud which by ye breade & wyne, are represented, he yt doth not put away al malice, rancor, & vncharitablenes from hys hert, & study to vnitie, loue, and concorde which by this mistical breade is betokened vnto vs, he that doth not come vnto this feast & banket with a mery hert, geuing god herty thankes, for our delyueraunce out of synne, he which dothe not much more eat ye death of the lord in his hert, then ye bread wt his mouth, is giltye of ye body and bloud of ye lorde and so he doth eate and drinke his owne dampnation, because he maketh no difference of ye lordes body, yt is to say, putteth no difference betwene this eatinge & other eating, which serueth onelye for the bealy, where as this eating was instituted & ordained to serue the soule & inward man. And therfore he yt abuseth it to yt flesh, eateth & drinketh his owne dampnatyon, and commeth vnworthely to the banket where the sacramente of Christes bodye, is eaten, yea, where ye body of ye lord is eaten, not carnally with the rethe and bealy: but spiritually with hearte, faith, and spirite. These phrases, I saye, and maner
of speaking do the holye fathers vse many times, when they do intreat vpō this sacrament, which at the first sight, maye seme to avow the bodely and carnal presence of Christ, in the sacrament & holye supper, but if they be wel pondered, mē shal sone perceiue & vnderstand howthei ought to be taken. For it is the custome & vse of the auncient doctors, when they speake of the sacrament & outwarde eating, to apply vnto the sacrament & outward eating, the frutes, profites, & conditions of the spiritual & inward eatinge, & also of the thing it self, which by ye sacrament is signified. Because yt in a faithful man, thei are so ioyntly ioined, yt the one is neuer without yt other: As by example we say yt god died & suffered for vs, & yet the godhead of Christ, by the which part onely he is called god, dyd neuer suffer. But because yt the godhead is so anexed wt the manhod, that they both make but one person, it is said yt god suffered for vs Which thing, if it be wel loked vpon, cōsidered & weied, shal be fonde to be an abused & an vnpropre speache, & yet neuertheles, it may wel be vsed, if men vnderstand what is meant therby. A very like
example haue we in the thirde of Ihon. Where Christ saith, no man ascendeth in to heauen, but he yt descendeth frō heauē the son of man which is in heauē. Mark & vnderstand: this scripture doth say & testifye, that the sonne of manne was then in heauen, when he spake these wordes, vnto Nicodemus, here vpon earth, whiche thing al wisemen do graunt yt it was spoken. propter vnitatem personae, yt is too say, for the vnitie of yt persō. For though his godhead were in euery place at that time, yet was not his manhod, by ye whiche he is called ye sonne of man, in heauē at yt time: And yet Christ said yt it was in heauē for his vnitie of ye persō. For hys godhead was in heauen, & because yt the godhead & manhode do make one persō therfore yt was adscrybed vnto the manhode, which was verified vpō ye godhed But now by the sacrament of baptisme we wil make this our matter more manifest & plain. In this sacrament (I meane baptisme) the inward working of the holy gost, is euer in the faithful persons, annexed vnto ye outward ceremonies: Therfore sometime the fruicte of the inwarde baptisme is adscribed vnto the outward
worke, & so ye scripture vseth to speake of ye outward baptisme, as though it wer ye inward, yt is to say, ye holy gost. And therfore S. Paul doth saye, yt we are buryed wt Christ, through baptisme, & yet ye outward baptisme did but signify this buryal. And again Paul doth say, as mani as are baptised, haue put Christ vpon them And yet in dede our outward baptisme, doth but signify yt we haue put Christ vpon vs: But by yt inward baptisme, whyche is the water of life, & the spirit of god we haue in dede put hym on, we liue in him, & he in vs. Which thyng truely cannot be verified of yt outward baptisme in thē, which do not receiue it wt faith. For vnto them it is but a bare sygne, wherof they get no profit, but damnatiō. And verely so it is of ye sacrament & holy supper of our lord. For in it ye scripture & all the auncient doctors do adscribe vnto ye outward worke & ceremony, which is onely true in yt inward veritie. For they onely eat yt flesh of the lord, & drinke his bloud not carnally wt teth & mouth: but spiritually wt faith. which dwel in Christ, and in whō Christ dwelleth: The veritie it selfe saying: he yt eateth my flesshe, & drinketh
my bloud, dwelleth in mee, & I in hym. Thus ye may se, how ye holy fathers of ye auncient & old church ought to be vnderstanded in this matter of ye sacramente & supper of ye lord. Which thei do cal Eucharistiam, a thankes geuing, because yt by it the faithful & godly, are moued too geue high & immortal thankes vnto god, their heauenly father, for ye death of his onely begotten son, Iesu Christ. Sometime Sinaxin, yt is to say, a charitable cōming together of ye faithful, vnto thys holy maūdy & feast of euerlastinge life. And otherwhiles a sacrifice, because yt as Chrisostō saith, it is a memorial of ye omnisufficient sacrifice, ones for euer offered in ye altare of ye crosse. Yea ye very missaries (yt truth compelling thē to ye same) do cal it ye mystery of faith, & the sacrifice of laude and praise. These thinges therfore, good chrysten reader, yu shalte depely prynte in thy mind & memory, yt thou maieste herafter wtstand ye enemies of ye truth, which euery where do bost & crake, yt the holy doctors do stand & make for thē, where as yf they be wel vnderstanded, they do all againste them. For that whiche they doo brynge out of Cipryan and Ambrose, all godly learned men do agre, that they
they were not Cipryans nor Ambroses workes, but workes falsly adscribed vnto them, by such false antichristes as intēded to bryng in this erromus, doctryne into the churche of Christe. Therfore let no such sayinges moue the, but sticking to the spirit which quickeneth, studye wt al thy endeuour, to be made one body wt our head, Iesu Christ, which in his glorified body, sitteth on ye right hand of god the father, tyl his enemyes be made hys fote stole. As for my parte, I wil daily & hourely beseche that almighty lorde, the father of al mercy and comfort, whyche did send his onely begotten sonne, Iesu Christ into this world, with al plenitude of heauenly doctrine, bidding vs to hear him, as his welbeloued son, yt he vouchesafe with his spirit, to kindle▪ rauishe and inflame our heartes, to the feruente loue of his doctrine onely, yt so with one faith and one consent, reiecting the dreames & doctrines of men, we maye fede oure soules with the heauenly fode of the Scriptures and worde of god. To whō be prayse glory and honour for euer. Amen.

div.head: ¶ The godly sayinges of the old faithful fathers, vpon the sacrament of the body and bloude of Christ.
¶ Augustyne, in a Sermon made to the chyldren and infances, touchynge the sacramente.
div.p:
THat, which ye se in ye altare of god, ye dyd se it also, the nyghte before: But what it was, what it doth mean, and of how great a thyng it doth contayne a sacrament, ye haue not yet herd. That therfore which Thys Sacrament is a matter of faythe. ye do se, is bread, and that whiche is set before your eyes, is a cup: But touching that wherin your faith desireth to be instructed: The breade is the bodye of Christ, and the cup his bloude. Truely, this is brieflye spoken, and which paraduēture might
suffise the faith: But faith requireth further instructyon. For ye prophet sayth: except ye beleue ye shal not vnderstand. Therefore Esaie. vi. cha. ye may say vnto me nowe: Thou hast bidden vs to beleue, expound, yt we may vnderstand For suche an imaginatyon may rise in any mannes mynde: We know yt our lord Iesus Christe dyd take hys fleshe of ye Virgin Mary. He beyng an infant, did The carnall natiuite of Chryst is here shewed & declared. sucke, was broughte vp, dydde growe, and came to mans state He did suffer persecution of the Iues, he was hanged vpon the crosse, & there he dyed. He was buryed, and the thyrde daye he rose again. On what dai it pleased him, he did ascende into heauen. Thether dyd he carye vp hys body, from whence he shall come, too iudge the quycke and
the deade. There he is now sittynge on the ryght hand of the father. Howe can, ergo, yt bread be hys bodye, and the cuppe, or that whiche is in the cup, be his bloude? These thinges brethrē are therfore called sacraments because that in them, one thing is sene, and an other thinge vnderstanded. That which is sene hath a vysyble apperaunce or forme, but that whych is vnderstanded, hath a spiritual vtilitie & profit. If thou wilt thē vnderstand ye body of Christ hear the i. Cor. xii cha. We our selfs are the bodye of Christe. apostle, saying vnto ye faithfull: Ye are ye body of Christ, & hys membres. Therfore, if ye are ye body of Christ, & hys members your misteri is put vpon ye table of ye lord, and ye receiue also the mystery of the Lorde. To that which ye are, ye answere: Amen,
and in aunswearynge, yee subscribe vnto it. Thou dost heare therfore the body of Christ, and thou answerest. Amen. Be thou a membre of the body of Christ that thy Amen, may be true. Why is it therfore ministred in breade? Let vs here brynge nothyng of our owne, but heare ye apostle him self, which when he speaketh of the sacrament, saith Thoughe we be manye, we are one breade, and one bodye. Vnderstand i. Corinthi. x. and reioyce: Therein is vnytye, godlines, truth, and charitie. Though we be manye (saith he) we are one bread and one bodi: Remembre yt bread is not made of one corn: but of many. How ye bread is made. When ye were exorcised, ye were in a maner ground, when ye were baptized, ye were as a man should say, knode together
When ye did receyue the sanctification A mete or apt similitude and comparisō betwixt ye faithfull that are brought vnto ye faithe, and ye bread whych is made of manye cornes. of the holy gost, ye wer in a maner, baken. Be ye ye, whiche ye se, and receiue yt which ye are. The apostle did say this of ye bread. Now what we oughte to vnderstand of ye cup, though not one word therof is spoken, yet it declareth and sheweth itselfe sufficyently. For euen as, yt there may be one visyble forme of breade, manye Cornes are knode together in one (asthogh that were done, which the holy scripture doth saye of the faithful, they had al one mynd, & one Actes .iiii. cha hert to god) so remembre ye brethrē, wherof wine is made. Many How wine is made. grapes do hang vpō a cluster but ye licour of ye grapes, is confounded together in one. Soo our lord Iesus christ signifiyng vs, & willing vs to pertayn vnto
him, did consecrate vpon his bourd, ye mystery of our peace & The sacramēt is a mistery of vnitie & loue. vnitie. He yt receiueth the mistery of vnytye, and doth not kepe the knot & bonde of peace, doth not receiue the mistery for himselfe: but a witnes agaynst hymselfe: Ne no man ought to dout but that euery one of the faythfull, is made partaker of the body and bloude of Christe, when in baptisme, he is made a member of Christe, and that no man The yong babes being baptyzed▪ are also partakers of ye body of ye lord thoughe they do die afore yt thei do receue the sacramēt. is put or enstraunged from the partakynge of this breade, and of this cup, if he be in the vnitye of the body of Christ, though he doth depart out of this worlde, afore that he doth eate of thys bread, and drinke of this cuppe. For he can in no wise be depryued of yt partaking & benefyt of this sacramente, when he hath .
foūd & gotten ye self same thing yt the sacrament doth signifye.

div.head: ¶ Our of a sermon of S. Augustine, touchyng the sacramentes of the faythfull. made vpon the seconde holye daye of Easter.
div.p:
¶ Because that Christ hath suffered for vs, he hath betakē vnto vs in this sacramēt, his body & his bloud, whych he hath also made, euē vs our selfes. For we are also made his body, and by hys mercye wee are euen the same thynge that we receyue. Remembre that ones ye were not, and ye haue bene created. Ye were brought into ye floore How we are made ye lords breade, of the lorde, wyth the laboures of the Oxen, that is too saye, of them that did preache ye gospel, yee were thresshed. Whyles youre Cathechysme lasted, ye Cathechisme is as much to saie institutiō and teaching •
were kept in the barne. Ye did giue your names, & began to be
ground, with fastinges & exorcysmes. Afterwardes, ye came to ye water, & beyng knode, wer made the bread of the lord. Lo what ye haue receyued. Therefore as that whiche ye see, was made one, so be ye all one in louinge etche other, in kepyng emonge Let vs be one in loue as the bread is made one of many cornes. you, one fayth and hope and one indissoluble loue. Heretiques when they do receiue ye same, they do receiue a witnes against thē selues, because that they seke a diuisiō, wheras this breade doth betoken an vnitie. So ye wine was in manye clusters, & now is one. It is one in the swetenes of the cup, after ye pressing of the wine presse. And ye after your fasting and laboures, after your humylite & contrition of hearte, are in ye name of Christ, as if a man should say
come to the Chalice of Christe. There are ye vpō ye table, there are ye in the chalice. And together with vs ye are. For we receyue it together, we drynke it together, because we liue together. If any man do eat of this bread, he shal liue for euer, & the bread which I shall geue, is my flesh, which I shal geue for ye life Flesh is takē in thys place, I meane the flesh whyche doth not vnderstand, for a carnall man yt vnderstādeth al thinges after ye flesshe, & as they are spoken. Ye shall haue these wordes vpon Ihon, ye xxxv. treatye. of the world. When should flesh vnderstand howe he dydde call bread flesh? That is called flesh yt flesh doth not vnderstande, & much more flesshe doth not vnderstand it, because yt it is called flesh, for they were astonied atit & murmured emong thē selues thinking yt it could not be done. My flesh (saith he) for ye life of ye world. The faithfull do vnderstand the body of Christ, if they thē selues do not despise to be ye
body of Christe, let thē be made ye body of Christ, if they wil liue with the spirit of Christ. Onely the bodye of Christe, doth lyue with the spirite of Christ. Take ye hede my brethren, what I We can not liue wt the spirit of Christ except we be in the body of Christe. haue sayde. Thou arte a man and haste bothe a spiryte and a bodye. I vnderstand by the spirite, that which is called ye soule wherewyth thou beinge a man arte compacte and made. For thou doest consyste of soule and The spirit is takē in a man for the soule, bodye. Thou haste therfore an inuysyble spiryte, and a vysyble bodye, Tell me whether of thē hath his lyfe of the other. Hath thy spiryte hys lyfe of thy body or thy bodye of thy spiryte? All menne lyuynge wyll saye: wee haue lyfe of the spirit. And surely, he that can not answere this I can not tel whether he liueth
or not. What do aunsweare all men lyuynge? Truely we haue lyfe of oure spirite. Wylte thou thē liue with ye spiryt of Christ? Be thou in the body of Christe. Doth my body liue with thi spirit? My bodye lyueth with my spirit, and thy body liueth with thy spirit. The body of Christe, can not liue: but wt his spirit of He yt is not in the bodye of Christe dothe not liue in the spirite of Christ, & therfore he is not his, and ye eatynge of the sacramente profiteth him nothing. i. Corin. x. How sinners may be made thee bodye of Christe. Christ. Therfore ye Apostle S. Paule, expounding this breade saith: Though we be many, we are one breade and one bodye. O sacramente of godlines. Oh signe of vnitie. O bonde of charitie and loue. He that will liue hath wherewyth he may lyue, let hym come nere, let hym beleue, let him be incorrupted and quyckened. Lette hym notte goo from the ioynture and compage of the members. Let him
not be a rotten limme, which deserueth to be cut of, let hym not be croked, wherof he may be ashamed let him be fayre, plain & whole, let him cleaue to the bodye. Let hym lyue to God, thorow god. Let hym now labour in earthe, that afterwardes he maye lyue in heauen.

div.head: ¶ In the same Sermon.
div.p:
HE wyll that this meate and drinke, shuld be vnderstand The misticall bread & drink is yt feloshyp of the faytheful. to be yt felowship and societie of his body and of his membres, which is ye holy congregation in his predestinate and called, in his iustyfyed and glorified sainctes and faithful. Of yt which the fyrst is done The .iiii. degres of mans saluation. alredy, that is to say, predestination. The second and thyrd are done, be now a doing, and herafter shall be done, yt is to say, callling
and iustificatiō. The fourth is now in hope, & herafter shall be fulfilled in dede, yt is to saye, glorifyinge. The sacramente of this thing, is prepared in some place daily, and in some place, at certain appointed times, as vpon the sonday. And it is receyued The thynge signifyed bye the sacamente is vnto all mē that are partakers thereof vnto lyfe and to no man vnto destructiō. at ye table of ye lorde, of some vnto life, and of some vntoo destruction. But the thing it selfe, whose sacrament this is, is receyued of all men vnto lyfe, and of no man vnto destructiō, whosoeuer is partaker of it. For my flesh (saith he) is meate in dede, and my bloud is drinke in dede For sithe that men do onely desire and couet, with meate and drinke, to put awaye their hunger and thyrst: This meate onely (whiche maketh them, of whō it is taken, immortal and incorruptyble)
and thys drynke can do it, that is to saye, the felowshyp of the saynctes, where full & perfite peace and vnytye shal be. Wherefore, (as holy men of god, haue perceyued before vs) This meate is the feloship of ye sainctes. oure Lorde Iesus Christe, dyd betake hys body and his bloud in those thinges whiche can be Why Christe did betake vnto vs his bodi and bloude in breade & wine redacted into some one thynge of manye. For the one is made of many cornes. one: and the other doth runne together into one, oute of manye grapes. He Ihon .vi. cha. that eateth my flesshe, and drinketh my bloud, dwelleth in me, and I in hym. This is therfore An vngodlye person eateth nothing but thesigne though he receyue neuer soo often the sacramente. to eate that meat, and to drinke that drinke, to dwel in Christ, & to haue Christ dwelling in him And by thys, he that dwelleth not in Christe, and in whome Christ doth not dwel, doth neither
eat his flesh, nor drinke his bloud, though he doth eate and drinke the sacrament of so high a thing, to his own dampnatiō.

div.head: ¶ Augustin .i. quinquage. Psalme .xxxix.
div.p:
¶ That first sacrifice being abolisshed, ye brent offerings of rammes, Al the sacrifices of the old law were but fygures & shadous of that only sacrifice ones offred in the crosse, whiche sacryfyce endurethe for euer: nor we nede no more sacrifices but of praise and thankes geuinge. &c. The promys ones made is now perfourmed. gotes, calues, & other beastes, beinge taken awaye: The lord would none of them. Why would he none of thē, sith yt at ye first he wold haue thē? Because that they al were words of promise, and the words of promise, when that is come, whych they do promise, be not vsed or spokē A man is stil called a promyser, till he doth geue. When he hath geuen, he dothe chaunge hys wordes. He doth not saye styll: I wyll geue that whyche I haue promysed: but I haue gyuen, and soo he hath chaunged
hys words. Why did this word please hym fyrst, and why hath he chaunged it? Because it was a worde of that tyme, & for that time it dyd please. Whyles the promise lasted, it was spoken & vsed. But when that is geuen, which was promysed, the wordes of promise are taken away and the wordes of performaūce geuen. Therfore those sacrifyces, as wordes of promise, are taken away. What word of performaunce is geuē vs? That body which ye do knowe, whyche wold god ye knew not to your owne dampnation. Thou woldest Psalme .xxxix. no sacrifice (saith he) nor oblatyō. What then? Are we now left without a sacrifice? God forbid. For saith he, thou hast made me a body. Therfore thou woldest none of them, because thou
mighteste performe thys. The performynge of the promyses hath taken away the wordes of promyse. Thys was promysed wyth certayne signes. The sygnes be taken away, & the truth which was promised, is alreadi geuen and exhibited. We are in this body, we are partakers of this body. We knowe what we do receiue. And ye that knowe i. Cor. xi. cha. not, learne: and when yee haue learned, beware that ye receiue it not to your own dampnatiō. For he that eateth & drynketh vnworthely, doth eate & drinke hys owne dampnation. A body is made vntoo vs, let vs bee made perfite in the bodie.

div.head: ¶ August. in the .xxvi. treatie vpō Ihon.
div.p:
HOw manye do receiue of the altare, and dye? yea, by receauing do incurre
death? Wherfore the apostle i. Cor. xi. cha saith: He doth eate & drinke hys owne dampnation. For the morsel of the lorde, was poyson vnto Iudas, and yet he did receiue it, & when he had receiued it, ye enemy did entre into hym. Not because yt he had receiued any euil thyng: but because yt he being wicked, did receiue it wickedly. Marke ye therefore brethren. Eate ye thys spirytuall bread, spiritually. Bring innocēcie of life, to the altare. Though your sinnes be daily & quotidian, Let noo man come to the lordes table excepte he repente truely. let not them be deadly. Before yt ye come too ye altare, take ye hede what ye saye. And forgeue vs oure trespaces, as we forgiue them yt trespace against vs. Dost thou forgiue? it shalbe The lorde cannot be deceyued of any man. forgiuen vnto the. Come boldelye, it is bread, and not poyson.
But se whether thou doste forgeue or not, for if yu doest not forgiue, thou makest a lye, and liest vnto him, whom thou canst not beguyle. Thou mayest make a lie vnto god, but thou canst not God knoweth the tames and heartes of men. deceiue god. He knoweth what thou doest: He seeth the within, he examyneth ye wtin, he loketh vpō the wythin, he iudgeth the wtin, he doth either condempne or rewarde ye within. Therfore the fathers of them, yt is to saye wycked fathers of the wycked, murmuring fathers, of murmurers. (For we do not reade, yt euer Murmuring is one of thee gretest sinnes against god. ye lord was so greuously offended wt any thing, as wt murmuring against God) the lorde willing to shew that they were the chyldren of suche, beganne wt them, after this maner: what doo ye murmure emonge you, O ye murmurers, chyldren of
murmurers. Your fathers did eate Manna in the deserte, and are dead. Not because yt Manna was euyll, but because that they dyd eat it wickedly. This is the breade whyche commeth doun from heauen. Manna did Manna was a figure of Christ, ye heauenly breade The sacramētes of ye old & new testamēt did differre in signes, but in ye thing which is signyfyed they be al one i. Corinthi. x. signify this bread, the altar did signify this breade. They were sacramentes, and dyd dyffer in signes, but in the thing, whyche is signified, they be al one. Hear the Apostle: For I wyl not that ye be ignoraunt, brethren, that our fathers were all vnder the cloude, and went al thorow the Sea, and were all baptized by Moses, in the cloud, and in the sea, and al dyd eate one spiritual meate: Euen the same spirytuall meate, albeit, an other bodely meat. For they didde eate Manna, & we do eate an other
thing. But they did eate ye same spiritual, that we do: but our fathers, vnto whome we are like, and not theirs. Moreouer, he saith, & they did drynke all one spiritual drinke, thei dranke one thinge, and we an other. But ye was in the outward apperaūce which neuertheles did signifye the selfe same thing spiritually. And how did thei drinke al one drinke? sayth the apostle: They did drinke of the spiritual rocke that foloweth thē, and ye rocke was Christe. Thereof haue we bread, thereof haue we drinke. The rocke was Christ, in signe and fygure, now is yt very true Christ in the word, & in the flesh And how did they drinke? The rocke was twise smitten wt the Exod. vii. cha. rod. The twise smiting, did sygnifie the two peces of the crosse
This is therefore the breade yt commeth downe from heauen, wherof yf any man dothe eate, It must be a spiritual eatynge. he shal not dye: But he that pertayneth to the vertue of the sacramente, not hee that partayneth to the visyble sygne. He ye eateth inwardly, and not outewardly. He that eateth wt his hert, not he yt presseth with hys tethe. Manna came downe frō heauen: But Manna was a shadowe, and thys is a veritie.

div.head: Augustine, vpon the wordes of Christe, the .lxiii. Sermon.
div.p:
¶ Moste dere beloued, we be i. Ihon. iii cha the chyldren of God, by grace, by faythe, by the Sacramente, by the bloude of Christe, by the redemptyon of oure sauyoure, we are the chyldren of GOD: It didde not yet appeare what
we shall be. We know that whē he doth appere, we shall be lyke vnto him. For we shall se hym, euē as he is. Lo, to what thing Spirituall meate is not minysshed. we are nourisshed, to receiue & eate, and yet notwithstandyng that thing which is eatē, is not minisshed, wheras he that doth eate is quickened. Other meat though in eating it quickeneth the bodye, yet when it is eaten it is mynysshed: But when we shall begynne too eate ryghteousenes, too eate wysedome, to eate that immortal meate, both we shall be quyckened, and the meate not mynysshed. Yf some excellente meate were praysed vntoo thee, whyche thou shouldest Agaynst thys holy supper we muste prepare our soules & not our bealyes. eate at thy diner, thou woldeste prepare thy bealye, nowe God is praysed vntoo the, prepare thy soule.

div.head: ¶ Augustine, vpon the wordes of the apostle, the second Sermon.
div.p:
¶ When he therfore, betakyng vnto vs suche meate and suche Ihon .vi. Cha drynke, did saye, excepte ye eate my flesh, and drinke my bloude, ye shal not haue life in you. Did any other thē life it selfe, speake these wordes of lyfe? But it wil be death vntoo that man, & not life, that thinketh life to be a lyer. His disciples wer offended, not all, but many: saying to thēselues. This is an harde saying who can heare it? What meaneth thys? Doth thys offende you? Do ye thinke that I wyll make partes of this body, & cut in sunder my membres, & geue them vnto you? What, yf ye do Christ coulde not be consumed. se the sonne of man, ascendynge where he was before? Truely, he yt ascendeth wholl, can not be consumed. Therefore he dydde
both geue vnto vs an wholsom refection of his body, and of his bloud, and also did brieflie assoil that hard question of his wholnes. Let them eate thē, that do What is too eate yt spirituall meate & drinke yt spirituall drinke. eate, and drinke that do drinke let them hunger and thirst. Let them eate lyfe, let them drynke lyfe. That eating is a refection in dede, and yet thou art so refectyoned, that thou canste not lacke, wherof to be refectioned. What other thing here, is it to drinke, but too lyue? Eate lyfe, drinke lyfe, and thou shalt haue life, & yet the life is whole. But that wyl be, that is too saye, the body and bloud of Christe, shall be lyfe vnto euery man, yf that which is taken visibly in the sacrament, be eaten and dronken spiritually in the veritie it selfe. For we haue herd the lord say:
It is the spirit that quickeneth the flesshe profiteth nothinge. Ihon .vi. cha The wordes that I haue spoken vnto you, are spirite & lyfe.

div.head: Augustine, in the .xxi. boke of the citie of God, and .xv. Chapiter.
div.p:
¶ This is the bread that commeth downe from heauen, if any man eateth of it, he shall not Ihon .vi. cha die. I am the liuely breade that commeth downe from heauen, if anye manne doth eate of this bread, he shal liue for euer. Not without a cause, it is asked how it ought to be taken. And from them truely, vnto whom we answere nowe, they vnto whome we shall aunswere hereafter do take away thys vnderstanding These be they yt promyse thys delyueraunce, not to all theym that haue receiued the Sacrament of baptisme, & of the body
of Christ: but too the catholyke onely, though they liue wickedly. For (say thei) they do not onely eat in the sacrament or sacramentally: but in very dede, ye body of Christ, and yt because that they are in his body, of ye which body, ye apostle saithe: Thoughe i. Corin. x we be many, we be one bread, & one body. Ergo, he which is in ye vnitie of his body (yt is to say, in ye knot of ye membres of Christ) Who be the trewe eaters. of the which body ye faithfull in their communion, are wonte to receiue ye sacrament, we oughte (I say) verely to esteme, that he doth eat ye body of Christe, and drinke his blud. And by this, he ritikes & scismatikes being deuided frō ye vnitie of thys body, maye receiue yt selfe same sacramēt: but not holsom & profitable vnto them, but rather noisom &
hurtful, Whereby they shal the sooner be condemned, or the later be delyuered. For they are not in yt knot & bonde of peace, Peace & vnite is expressed in the sacramēt. which is expressed in this sacramente.

div.head: ¶ In that same Chapiter.
div.p:
¶ He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my bloud, dwelleth in mee, and I in him. He sheweth what is to eat, not sacramental lye, but in very dede the bodye of Christ, & to drinke his bloud. For that is to dwell in Christe, that Christ may dwel in vs, for Vnitie & loue onely dothe fede vpon the body & bloud of Christe. he dyd speake thys thynge, asthough he should say: he whych dwelleth not in me, and in whō I do not dwell, let him not saye or thinke that he eateth my body, or drinketh my bloud. They do not therfore dwell in Christ which are not his lymmes, but
they are not his limmes, which make theym selues ye membres of an harlotte.

div.head: ¶ Augustine vpon Ihon .xxvi. treatye.
div.p: ¶ He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my bloud, dwelleth in me, and I in him. This is therfore By these wordes ye may se that the sacrament is not ye very body of Christ else the wicked which dwelleth not in Christ shuld eate his fleshe to eate that meate, and too drinke that drinke, too dwell in Christ, and to haue Christ dwelling in him. And by this, he that dwelleth not in Christe, and in whom Christ doth not dwel, wt out doubt, he doth neither eate the flesh of Christe spirituallye, nor drinke his bloud, though he doth carnally and visibly presse with hys teth, the sacrament of the body and bloud of Christe.

div.head: ¶ Augustine the .xxvii. treatie, and .vi. Chapiter of Ihon.
div.p:
¶ And he did expound the maner of the distributyon of thys
hys gift, how he shuld giue hys flesh to eate, saying: He that eateth my flesshe. &c. This is a token, that he hath eatē & dronke The trewe waie to eate the bodye of Christe yf he dwel, and be dwelled with all, yf he dothe inhabite, and be inhabyted, yf he doth stycke fast vntoo, and be not forsaken. He hath therefore taught and warned vs, wyth these mistical wordes, that we shoulde be in hys body and members, vnder him as oure heade, eatyng his flesh and not forsakynge the vnytye of hys bodye.

div.head: If ye se the son of man ascending where he was before.
div.p:
¶ What is thys? wt these wordes he dothe assoile thē, whō he knewe: Wyth these wordes he doth declare & shew wherefore they wer offended, wt these wordes truly, if they mought haue
vnderstāded. For they thought that he shuld erogate and part his body emonge them: But he Why the ieues were offended. sayth, that he shall ascende into heauen whole: When ye shall se the sonne of manne ascendynge where he was before: Then truly ye shal se that he doth not distribute his body, after the maner that ye thynke. Verelye ye The grace of god can not be consumed shall vnderstand that his grace is not consumed wyth tethe.

div.head: Augustine .ii. quinquage. rcviii. Psalme
div.p:
¶ When the Lorde did betake thys vnto vs, he had spoken of hys flesshe, and sayde: Excepte a manne dothe eate my flesshe, he shall not haue in hym, lyfe euerlastynge. And he sayde, the wordes that I haue spoken vnto The natura • body of chri • is not eaten nor his blou • dronken. you, are spiryte and life. Vnder stande ye spiritually, yt whiche I haue spokē vnto you. Ye
shall not eate this body whiche ye se, nor drinke the bloud whiche they shal shede, that shal crucifie me.

div.head: ¶ Augustine in the third boke of the Chrysty an doctryne.
div.p: ¶ Excepte ye eate the flesshe of the sonne of man, & drynke hys bloude, ye shall not haue lyfe in you. He semeth to commaunde To eate, is to be partaker of the passion of Christe. a foule and wicked thing. Therfore it is a figure, cōmaundinge vs to be partakers of ye lordes passion, and to printe in our memory swetly, that his flesh was crucifyed and wounded for vs.

div.head: ¶ In the decrees of penaunce, ye seconde distinction vpon charitie and loue, these wordes of S. Augustin are founde.
div.p:
¶ Also the lorde. I am the lyuely bread that came doune from heauen, if any man doth eate of
this bread, he shal lyue for euer He therfore that doth not lyue for euer, did neuer eat this liuely breade. But he that hath not eaten, dyd not beleue in hym. For this is to eate, that lyuelye To beleue in Christ is to eate his body and to drinke his bloude. breade, to beleue in Christ, that is to say, with loue, to sticke fast vnto Christe. Sith therefore ye the wicked dyd not beleue, he did not eate hym, and so he dyd wante the faith of ye Christians wherby onely sinnes are remitted.

div.head: ¶ Augustine, vpon the wordes of ye lord in Luke▪ xxviii. Sermon.
div.p:
¶ Geue vs this day, our dayly bread. When I dyd entreate of the sacrament, I did say vntoo you, that before the wordes of Christ, that, which is offered, is Marke howe that he saith it is called ye boby of Christ & not it is ye body of Christe. Christ is that supersubstantiall breade. bread: but after that ye wordes of Christe are spoken, it is noo
more called bread: but ye body of Christ. Therfore in ye lords praier, which foloweth, we say: giue vs yt supersubstancial bread, not this bread that goeth intoo the body: but that bread of euerlastyng life, which vpholdeth the substaunce of our soule.

div.head: ¶ This saying of S. Augustin is founde in the Canones of consecratyon, and in hys Epystle to Hierome.
div.p: ¶ The body of Christ, in ye whiche Ergo it is not where soeuere the sacrament is ministred. he did ryse, muste be in one place: but hys truthe is spreade throughout al the worlde.

div.head: Augustine, in his Epistle to Dardanus.
div.p:
¶ Therefore doubte not, but ye Iesus Christ, in yt he is a man is there, frō whence he shal come, Remembre and faithfully hold the Chrystyan confessyon, that he dyd ryse from deathe, ascended into heauen, and sytteth on
the ryght hande of God the father, Thys faith or article of oure faith thei doo destroi which aff • rme that ye very naturall body of christ is in the sacramente, and that he shall come frō none other place, too iudge the quycke and the deade. And he shal come (ye angels testifyinge ye same) as he was sene to go vp into heauē, yt is to say, in ye same fourme & substaunce of flesshe, vnto the whych truelye, he dyd giue immortalitie, but frō it hee did not take away the humayn nature. After this fourme, wee Heare we be warned too shunne ye heresye of the Marcionites which dyd affyrm yt Christ hath but a phantasticall body must not thinke yt he is in euery place. For we must beware that we do not so affirme the diuinitie of the manhod, yt we take away the truth of his body. For it foloweth not, that the thyng which is in god, shuld be in euery place, as god is. For the scripture dothe truely testifye vnto vs, that we liue, moue and be in hym, & yet are we not in euerye
place, as he is. But manne is otherwise in god, and god other wyse in man, by a certayne proper & singulare waye. For God and man is one person, & bothe Christ touchinge his manhod is in heauen & in eueri place toucheynge his godhed. of thē one Christ Iesus, whiche is in euery place, in yt he is god, and in heauen, in yt he is a man.

div.head: ¶ Augustine vpon Ihon, touchinge the wordes of the lorde, the .liii. Sermon.
div.p:
¶ The very true faythe dothe The churche whiche is the mistical body of Christ, is bi a certain maner of speach called Christe hold, yt the sauiour of the world was sente vnto vs. For Christe him self, yt is to say, the bodye of Christ, dispersed throughout al ye world, doth preche Christ. He was in heauē, and yet vnto him that persecuted rageously here in ye earth, he did say: Why dost thou persecute me? Where the lorde dyd expressely shewe, that he was here in vs. So he doth encrease and growe together
wholle: For euen as he is in vs here, soo we are there in hym. The knotte of loue and charytye Charite doth make vs one with god. dothe bringe that too passe. He that is our head, is the sauyour of his bodye. Ergo, Christe doth preache Christ. The body doth preache his heade, and the head doth defend his body, and therfore the world hateth vs. Whosoeuer will be in his body & in hys members, let him not maruayle, yf the worlde hateth him. Many do receyue ye sacrament Not all they yt receyue the sacramēt be sauede or incorperated wyth Christ of his body: but they shall not all that receyue it, haue the place with him,, which is promised vnto his members.

div.head: Augustin in his commentaries vpon the xxxiii. psalme.
div.p:
¶ A man may be borne with other He dothe expound himselfe in the .ii. sermone vpō the same psalm where he saith, he was borneafter a certaine maner in hys owne handes Moreouer this place is wel expoūded both in yt whiche goth here before & in yt whiche immediately foloweth. Marke these allusions and maner of speakynges, mens handes. Wyth hys owne handes no man is borne.
But christ was born wt
•• s own handes, whē he betaking his body, did say. This is mybody: for he did bear yt body in his hands

div.head: Augustine, to Bonifacius.
div.p:
¶ We often vse to say whē Easter draweth nigh, yt to morowe or ye next day, is ye lordes passyō. And yet it is manye yeres since he suffered, & that passyon was neuer done but ones. And vpō yt sonday we say: This daye the lord did rise again, and yet it is many yeres since he rose. Now is there no man so folish, too reproue vs as liers, for so saying. Because we name these dayes, after the simylytude of those in which ye thinges wer done, so yt it is called ye same day which is not ye very day: but by reuolution of time, like vnto it. And it is named to be done the same day for ye celebration of ye sacrament
which is not done that day, but was done long before. Was not Christ once crucified in his own person? & yet in a mistery he is crucified for the people, not onely euery feast of Easter: but euery day. Neither doth he lie, whiche (whē he is asked) answereth that he is crucified. For if the sacramentes The sacramētes doo take ye names of the verye thinges whereof they are sacramentes. had not certain similitudes, of those things wherof they are sacraments, thē shuld they be noo sacramentes at all. And for this symilitude, for the most part, they take ye names of ye very thinges. And therfore after a certain maner, ye sacramēt of Christes body, is Christes body, & the sacrament of Christes bloud, is Christes bloud. And ye sacrament of faith, is fayth. For it is none other thing to beleue thē to haue faith. And therfore when a man aunsweareth that
the infant beleueth (which hath not yet the affect of faith) he answereth that he hath fayth, for the sacramente of faithe. And ye he turneth hym selfe vnto god, for the sacrament of conuersyō. For the answere pertaineth vnto ye ministring of the sacramēt As the apostle wryteth of baptisme. We are buryed (saith he) Baptisme signifyeth buryyng and yet ye apostell saieth not we signifi burymge but we are buried so yt this verbe est, is, muste be here taken for it signifieth Christe in his laste Suppere dyd delyuer ye figure of hys bodi vnto his disciples. wt Christ, through baptisme, vnto death-He saith not: We signifie burying, but vtterly he saith We are buried. He called therefore the sacrament of so highe a thing, euē wyth ye propre name of the very thing it selfe.

div.head: ¶ Augustine in the preface of ye .iii. Psal.
div.p: ¶ He admitted him (speakinge of Iudas) vnto ye banket, when he dyd betake & delyuer vntoo his disciples, ye figur of his bodi

div.head: Augustine to Adamantus.
div.p: ¶ The lord doubted not to say This is my body, when he The lorde sayeth this is mi • odi whan he gaue a fygure of it. gaue a signe, or figure of his bodye. For truely (saith he, by and by after in the same chapiter) so the bloud is the soule as Christ was the stone. And yet the apostle dyd not saye: The stone did signifie Christ, but ye stone was Christe.

div.head: Prosper, in the boke of sentences.
div.p: ¶ He that dwelleth in Christ, & He that by sagreethe from Christe doeth not eate hys flesshe, nor drinke hys bloude. whose geast Christe is, doth receiue ye meate of life, & drinketh the cup of eternitie. For he that discordeth frō Christ, doth neyther eate his flesshe nor drynke his blud, although he receiueth indifferently euery daye, the sacrament of so high a thyng, too the condemnatyon of hys presumptiousnes.

div.head: Ambrose vpon the sacramentes.
div.p: ¶ This breade that goeth into the bodye, is not soo greadelye The bread of euerlastynge life is soughte of vs. sought of vs, but ye breade of euerlastinglife, which vpholdeth yt substaunce of the soul. For he yt disagreeth from Christe, dothe not eat his flesh, nor drinke his bloud, although he receiueth ye sacrament of so high a thyng, to his vtter damnatiō & vndoing.

div.head: Ambrose vpon yt epistle to ye Cori. xi. cha vpon this saying: Shewe ye lordes death
div.p: ¶ Because that we wer deliuered, by the death of the lord, we, Here he meaneth the sacramente. in eating and drinkyng of thys thing, do signify the flesshe and bloud, whyche were offered for vs.

div.head: Ambrose, vpon the sacraments .iiii. boke
div.p:
But paraduenture yu wilt say: I se no appearaunce of bloude, We drynke a similitude of Christes blud but it hath a similytude. For euen as thou hast taken the similytude
of deathe, euen soo thou drinkest the similitude of ye precious bloud.

div.head: Tertullian in ye .ii. boke against Marcion
div.p: ¶ Christe hym selfe did not reproue Marciō was an heritike which dyd reproue al creaturs saiyng yt they wer euil Marcion dyd affyrme that Christe hath a phantastical body, whiche opinion, thys holy doctour dothe oppugne wt thee sacramente which coulde not haue bene a figur of christes body, excepte hee had a trewe body▪ or discommende breade, wher wt he doth represent hys bodye.

div.head: Tertullian, in ye .iiii. boke against Marciō
div.p: ¶ Christ taking bread, & distributinge it vntoo hys disciples made it his bodi, saiing. This is my body, that is to say, the fygure of my bodye: But thys bread could not haue bene a fygure of it, except christ had had a true bodye. For a vaine thing or phantastycall can take noo fygure.

div.head: Origene vpon Leuiticus, ye .vii. Homely.
div.p:
¶ Vnderstande that they are fygures, whyche are wrytten in the Scryptures of GOD.
And therfore examine them, as spirytuall men, and not as carnall. Vnderstand those thinges which are spoken-For if ye take or vnderstand those thinges as carnall men, they do hurte, and not nourysshe. For there is also in the gospell, a letter yt killeth. Not onely in the old testament In the newe testamēt there is also a letter that killeth. a killing letter is found: but also there is in the new testament, a letter which killeth him, yt doth not vnderstande those thinges spirituallye, whiche are spoken. For if thou doest folowe after ye letter, thys that is spoken: Except Iho. vi. chap. ye eat my flesh and drynke my bloude, thys letter killethe. Wilt thou that I bryng vnto ye out of the new testament, an other letter yt kylleth? He yt hath no knife (saith he) let him sel his cote & bie one. Lo, this letter is Luke .xxii. cha
of the gospell, and yet it killeth But if thou takest it spiritually it kylleth not: but in it is a quickening spirit. Therefore vnderstand spiritually those thynges whyche are spoken, whether it be in the lawe, or in the gospell For a spirytuall man dyscusseth al thynges, and is iudged of no man.

div.head: In the same boke, the .ix. Homelye.
div.p: And thou whych art come to ye true bisshop which wt his bloud hath purchased vnto the, ye mercy of god, & hath reconciled the vnto his father, doo not stycke to the bloud of ye flesh: but lerne rather the bloud of the worde. And heare him that saythe.

This is my bloud whych The flesh and blud of godes word must be sought. shal be shed, for the remissyon of youre synnes. He
which is taught in the misteryes, doth know the flesh & bloud of the word of god.

div.head: Athanasius vpō this saying of Christ, he yt shall speake a word against ye holy gost
div.p:
¶ It is the spirit that quyckeneth, the flesh profiteth nothing Ihon .vi. cha the wordes whych I spake vntoo you, are spirite & life. For in this place also he meaneth both of his own flesh, & his owne spirit: And he deuideth ye spirit frō the flesh, that they might know through faith, not onely the visible part, but also ye inuisible part that was in him,, & also that the words which he spake, wer not carnal, but spirituall. For what bodi shuld haue suffised, to haue No carnal body can suffice to be yt meate of all the worlde bene ye meat of al ye world? And therfore did he make mentiō of the goyng vp of ye son of man in to heauen, yt he might wt drawe
thē, frō the bodely imagination and yt they might herafter lern Why Christ dyd make mētion of his ascendyng into heauen. yt the flesh was called heauenly meat, whych commeth from aboue, & the spiritual meat whyche he wold geue. For (saith he) the wordes that I haue spoken Ihon .vi. cha vnto you, are spirite and lyfe.

div.head: Bede vpon Luke.
div.p: ¶ After ye solempnitie of ye olde Why ye solemnite of ye Easter lamb was kepte Easter lamb was finisshed, whiche was obserued in ye memory al of the old deliueraūce oute of Egipt, he passeth furth vnto the new (which ye church gladly obserueth in ye remembraunce of their redemptiō) yt he in ye stead Christ did ordayne ye sacrament of his owne fleshe & bloude, in the figur of bread and wyne. of the flesh & bloud of the lambe might institute & ordain the sacrament of his own flesshe and blud, in the figure of bread and wine, & so declare him self, to be the same vnto whom the lorde sware.

Thou art a perpetual priest, after the ordre of Melchisedeche And he him self brake the bread which he gaue, to shew that the breaking of his body, shuld not be done without his wyll. And The breaking of christes bodye was nott done without hys will. Why ye bread is referred vnto his body • the wine vnto his bloude. likewise he gaue thē the cup, after he had supped. And because bread doth confyrme and corroborate the flesh, and wyne worketh bloud in the flesshe: Therefore is the bread misticallye referred vnto the body of Christ, and the wyne vnto his bloude.

div.head: Barnard, vpon the psalme, qui habitat: the third verse, and the .iii. Sermon.
div.p:
¶ Except ye eat the flesh of the
• hon .vi. cha. son of man & drinke his blud. &c They said: This is a harde saying, and so went away backe frō him: But what is it to eate hys flesh, and to drinke hys bloude: but to be partakers of his passion,
and to folow that conuersation whiche he dyd vse here in the flesh? Which thyng yt moste holy sacrament, in ye whiche we The bread entreth into the mouthe, but Christe into ye hearte. receyue the bodye of the lorde, doth signifie, that is to say, yt as the forme of bread is sene to entre into vs, so we must knowe, yt by that conuersation, whych he did vse in the earth, he entreth into vs, to dwell, through faith in our heartes. For when righteousnes dothe entre, he dothe i. Corinthi. i. entre also, whiche of god the father is made vntoo vs ryghteousnes. &c.

div.head: Gelasius Bishop of Rome, againste the Entichians in the councyle of Rome.
div.p:
¶ Surely the sacramentes of the body and bloud of Chryste, are godly and diuine thinges, & therfore through them, are we made partakers of the diuyne.
& godly nature. And yet dothe Thys surelye was the olde learning whiche by ye subtil craft of the deuyl was subuerted. it doth not cease too be the substaunce of breade and wine, but contynue stil in the propertie of their owne nature. And surely, the image and similitude of the body and bloud of Christ, are celebrated in ye act of ye misteries.

div.head: Fulgentius, in the seconde boke of faith
div.p:
¶ In these carnal sacrifices, in As the sacryfices of the old lawe were shadowes of the flesh of Christ which should be offred, so ye sacrament is a figure of it beyng alredy offered. Marke yt hee doth cal it a sacrifice, which neuertheles is but a remembraunce of ye
• nely sacrifice ye time of the law, was a signifycation of ye flesh of Christ, which he wtout sin, shuld offer for our sinnes, & of the bloud, which he shuld shede for ye remissiō of our sinnes: But thys sacryfyce is of thankes geuinge & remēbraūce of the flesh of Christ, which he offered for vs, & of the bloud, whiche ye same god did shede for vs

div.head: ¶ Idem, in his boke to kinge Thrasymundus.
div.p:
¶ This cup or chalice, is ye new testament: yt is to say, this cup
or chalice, which I deliuer vnto you, doth signifi ye new testamēt

div.head: Idem in the second boke.
div.p:
The same one man is local as Christ beinge a man is locall, that is to saye is cōteyned in one place onely. touching his manhod, which is also God vnmeasurable frō the father. Thesame one mā, as touching the substaūce of his manhod, was absent from heauen, when he was in ye earth: & forsaking ye earth when he ascended into heauen: But as touchinge his godheade, & vnmeasurable substaunce, he neyther forsoke heauen, when he descended frō heauē, nor forsoke ye earth, whē he ascended into heauē. Whych maye be knowen by this moste How Christe did shewe his humanitye to bee locall and his godheade to be presente in euery place sure worde of the Lorde, whyche to shewe hys humanytie, to be contained in one place onely dyd saye vntoo his disciples. I ascend vnto my father, & youre father, my God, and your God.
Of Lazarus also, when he said Lazarus is dead. He saide further more: I am glad for youre sakes (that ye myghte beleue) yt I was not there. And agayne, shewing the vnmeasurablenes of his godhed, he said vnto hys disciples: Beholde, I am wyth you to the worldes ende. How did he ascende into heauen: but because he was locall, and a very man? Or how is he presente vnto his faithfull: but because yt he is vnmeasurable, and verye God?

div.head: Hierome in his cōmentaries vpon Mathewe .xxvi. Chapiter.
div.p:
¶ After yt the mystycall Easter lambe was fulfylled, and that Christe had eaten the lambes flesh, with his Apostles, he toke breade, whyche conforteth the hert of man, and passeth furthe
to the true sacrament of the Easter Here Hierom wt holy Tertulian doth hold against ye heretike Marcion lambe, yt as Melchisedeche brought furth bread and wyne in prefiguratyon of hym, soo he myght lykewyse represente the truth of his bodye.

div.head: Hierom vpon Ecclesiastes, that is to say the boke of the preacher
div.p: ¶ The flesh of the lord is very meate, and the bloud of the lord We do eate ye body of Christ and drinke his bloud in the redynge of the scriptures. is verye drinke. We haue thys good or profyte onelye, in thys worlde, that we maye eate hys flesh, and drynke hys bloud, not onely in a misterye, but alsoo in the readyng of the scryptures. For it is very meat and drinke, which is taken oute of goddes word, by the knowledge of the scriptures.

div.head: ❧ Hierome vpon the .C. ix. Psalme. and .viii. Tome.
div.p:
¶ Thou art a perpetual priest,
after ye ordre of Melchisedeche Let vs declare onely, whye he did say, after the order of Melchisedech. Thys trewlye is as muche to say: Thou shalt not be a priest after the Iuisshe oblatyons: But thou shalt be a prieste after ye order of Melchisedeche For as Melchisedech dyd offer or bring furth bread and wyne, The bodye & bloud of christ is the trewe breade & the trew wine Melchisadech was kynge of Salem. so thou shalt offer thy body, and thy bloude, whych is the trewe bread and wyne. Thys Melchisedech did giue those mysteries that we haue, vntoo vs. It is he that sayde: He that eatethe my flesshe, and drynketh mye bloude. &c. After the ordre of Melchisedech, he dyd gyue his sacrament vnto vs.

div.head: ☞ Hierom in his cōmentaries vpon the Epistle of Paule to the Ephesyans.
div.p:
¶ The flesh and blud of Chryst
is taken or vnderstanded .ii. waies. The flesh and blud of Christ is vnderstanded .ii. wayes Either that spirituall and diuine flesh, of the which he saith: My flesh is verye meate, & my bloud is verye drynke. Or that flesh which was crucyfyed, or ye bloud which was shed with the speare of the souldyer.

div.head: ❧ Chrisostom. vpon the .xxvi. of Mat.
div.p: ¶ He also dranke of it, lest whē they hearde hys wordes, they Chryste hymself did drinke of the cuppe a fore yt he gaue it to his apostles. should saye: Why? doo we then drinke bloude, and eate flesh? & so should be troubled, for when he spake before of those thyngs they were offended wyth hys wordes. And because it shoulde not nowe alsoo chaunce, he himselfe dranke fyrste of it, that he mighte cause them to come wt oute feare too the partaking of those mysteryes.

div.head: ❧ Idem .xvi. Homelye
div.p: ¶ The flesh profyteth nothing Ihon .vi. cha That is too saye: My wordes must be vnderstanded after the spirite. He that vnderstandeth them after the flesh; winneth no thing, nor taketh no profit therof. What meaneth this, too vnderstande after the flesh, or carnally? What is to vnderstand after the flesshe Verely to take the thynges simplie, as they are spoken and thynke none other thinge. All mysteries or sacramentes, must be considered wt inwarde eyes, that is to say, spirituallie. For the inward eies as sone as they do se the bread, do passe ouer the creatures, and thynke not of that bread which is bakē That heauenly bread whiche is Christe • s signified by ye sacramente of the baker: but of him that called him selfe the breade of lyfe, which is signified by the mystycall or sacramentall breade.

div.head: ❧ Chrisostom in his first Tome vpon ye viii. chapiter of Mathew, ye. xvi homelie.
div.p:
¶ It is against all reason, that we in verye dede enioying hys benefites dayly, shoulde not as muche as wt wordes, giue hym thankes: Sith that the same acknowledging The acknowledgynge of ye benyfites of god doth profite vs. & confession doth profit vnto vs. For he hath noo nede of any thing that is ours, but we haue nede of all that he hath. The giuynge of thankes addeth nothing vntoo him: but it maketh vs more familyares vnto his maiestie. For syth that when we remembre the benefytes of mē, we are the vehement lyer inflamed & kindeled, wyth the loue of them: Muche more Collo. iii. Cha •
if we be mindfull of the benefytes of god, we shall be the more studious to kepe his cōmaundements. Therfore yt apostle saith
Be ye thankful. For the remembraunce of benefits & perpetual thankes geuing, is a very good keper of benefits: wherfor these most reuerent & holsom misteries, which we do celebrate in euerye congregatyon, are called Why ye sacrament is called Eucharistia. Eucharistia, that is too saye thankes geuynge. For they are the remembraunce of many benefytes, and shew the head foūtaine of ye diulne charitie & loue toward vs, & causevs alwaies to giue due thankes vnto god.

div.head: ☞ Chrisostome vpon the .x. Chapyter, to the Hebrues, and .xvii. Homelye.
div.p:
¶ And thys that we do, we do in the remembraunce of yt whiche is done alreadye. For (saith he) do this in the remembraūce of me. We do not offer an other sacryfyce (as the Bisshop of the olde lawe) but alwaies the selfe
same, yea, rather we doo worke the memoryall & remembraūce Here holy Chrisostome and all other faythefull fathers doo vse thys worde • sacrifice for a memoriall & remēbraunce of that onely • sacrifice ones offred for euer as Augusty • also witnesseth in ye. xxx viii. boke agaynst Faustus much contrary to them which craftely haue brought and induced into ye church of Christ this cursed sacrifice of yt mass •
of that sacryfyce: But because yt I haue made mentyon of thys sacryfyce. I wyll speake fewe thynges vntoo you, fewe thynges in numbre and measure: but whiche haue greate vertue and vtilitie. Whiche remembre ye, and prynt in youre mindes. For the thinges that are spokē, be not ours, but the holy gostes What be they thē?
