Very many do receiue of this sacrifice ones in the wholl yeare, some twyse, some oftener. Therefore we generally to al, not onely to thē yt be here: but also to thē yt sit in ye wildernes. For they do partycipate ones in ye yeare, yea, perchaūce after two yeares: What then? Whome doo we accepte most? Them that receiue it but ones, or them yt receyue it often
or them that communycate seldome? Verelye we neyther accept them that receyue it ones, They yt come to ye lordes table wt a pure conscience are to be prefered before al other and to be accepted. nor them that receyue it often, nor them that communicate seldome, but them that come vnto it wyth a pure conscyence, with a cleane heart, with a blameles life. And they that are not such, do not receyue it as much as ones: why so? for they do receiue their own dampnation and vtter
• ▪ Cor. xi. cha vndoyng.

div.head: ☞ Chrisostome out of the oratyon of S. Philogonius.
div.p:
¶ Many christen men are now come to yt madnes, and are growen to so great a contempte, yt where as they be ful of innumerable vyces, they nothynge regard The tyme of • cōmunyon • s no holy day • ut of pure cō
• ience. their own life, but vpō holy daies, do come negligently & rechelously vntoo this bourde,
not knowing yt the time, of ye cōmunion, is neither holy day nor solempnitie: but a pure conscyence, & a life cleane from sinnes.

div.head: ☞ Chrisostome out of the .xxvii. homelie touchinge his retourne from Asia to Constantinopol.
div.p: ¶ We are not like the Iues, we In ye matter of ye sacramēt we are neyther bound to place nor to tyme. are neither subiect to place nor to time, being confirmed wt the saying of the lord. As oftē (saith he) as ye eat of this breade, and drinke of this cup, ye shal shewe furth the lordes death. To day then we shew the lordes death: But then an holy day, & now to day also a holy day.

div.head: ☞ Chrisostō in his .i. Tome .li. Homelie,
div.p:
¶ For this sacrament is a sacramēt The sacrament is a sacramente of peace. of peace, which doth not agre with couetousnes of money nor with simonie. For if he dyd not spare him self for our sakes
what punishment do we not deserue, if we spare not our soules Iudas for couiteousnes of money sould Christ, and so he did perissh Simon wold haue boughte the gyfte of ye holy ghost for money, yt hee myght be enriched therby wherefore all they that bye or sel any spirituall giftes for lucre and money are called after thys Simon Magus Simoniakes. The trew honoure of thys sacrifyce. for the which Christe dyd gyue him selfe, and in the meane season do spare money? Therfore let no Iudas nor Simon come to that table which both did perish for couetousnes of money. Wherfore let vs I pray, auoyd and exchew this parilouse pyt, nor let vs not thynke that it is sufficient for oure saluatyon, yf when we haue spoyled wyddowes and fatherles children, we offer vnto this table, a chalice of gold, trimmed wyth precyouse stones. Wilt thou honour thys sacryfyce? Offer thy soule, for yu whiche Christe was crucyfyed, make it golden. For if thy soule be a vessell of leade, what shall golden vessels profyte thee?

And verelye that (table was Superfluouse coste in churches is discommendyd.
not of siluer, nor that chalice of gold, wherin christ did giue his blud, to his disciples, and yet al thynges wer precyous, & ful of veneration and worshippe. For they were ful of the spirit. Wilt thou worship ye body of Christ? How ye body of Christ must be worshiped Despyse hym not naked in hys members, nor do not cloth him with sylkes in the churche, and suffer him negligentlye abrode to be storued for colde and nakednes. For he ye saeth: Thys is my body, and together wt Vnderstande here that as ye lambe beyng taken oute of the flocke and applied to the sacrifices of ye passeouer is called ye passeouer of the lorde so is ye bread whiche is broken in the remembraunce of the body of Christe called the body of Christ. It is the greatest honour yt we can do vnto god, if we do fulfyll his wil & worship him as he hath taughte vs in his word the worde, dyd bryng the thing to passe, sayth also: ye haue sene me hungrye, and yee haue not fedde me. And in so muche that ye dydde not it too one of these little ones, ye dydde it not vnto mee,

this body of Christ (meanyng yt which is ministred in the sacrament) hath no nede of gayeclothing: but ye other body (here he doth vnderstand the poor membres of Christe) hath neade of greate care and dilygence. Let vs therefore learne to be trew phylosophers in Christe Iesu, and to worshyp hym after hys owne wyll. For he whyche is worshypped, delyteth moste in that worshyppe, whiche he himselfe wyll haue, not in that whiche we prescribe vnto him, So Peter thought that he dyd honoure Christe, when he woulde not suffre him to wash his fete: but it was contrarie. Likewise worshyppe thou hym, as he wil be worshypped, laye abrode thy ryches too the poore. There is noo neade of golden vessels, but
of golden soules. Aunswere me (I pray) what profit is it, if whē his table in decked wyth many suche golden cuppes, he him self perissheth for hunger? Therefore The poore must be cared for afore al other thinges. fede hym firste, and after yu shalt decke his table, as of a superabundaunce. Thou doste make him a chalice of gold, and thou wilt not geue him a cup of cold water. What profite doth folow therof? The couerynges Thys godlye lerninge hath bene long hidden from • s. of his table, do shine with golde and yu denaiest vnto him necessary raymentes. What dost thou geue him then? Cell me, I pray the, if thou shouldest se a man almost dead for hunger, and woldest not succour his necessitye, wyth some meate: but decke a table before hym wyth muche golde and syluer? What thankes thinkest thou would yt man giue vnto the? What if yu shouldeste
se a man almoste frosen wt cold, & woldest prepare no necessary raimēts for him, but set vp goldē images in ye honor of him shuldest yu not seme to cōtempne him? So it behoueth ye to think in Christ. When he goeth about wandering, as a straunger, lacking harbor, then yu dost not receiue hym, & in ye mean season, yu dost trim ye pauings of churches Thou makest vp costly walles, yu settest vp gorgious heades of pillars, thou causest lampes to hang down frō golden sielyngs & in ye mean season thou dost not visite him being in prison. Noo No man was euer blamede because he had not buylded gorgious churchis man was euer blamed or accused because he had not buylded vp costly temples or churches. But euerlasting fire of hel (ye punishment of the deuils) do hang ouer vs, except we doo thother thinges diligentlye.

div.head: ¶ To all theim yt do professe ye truth and veritie of our lord, Ihon Veron wissheth grace, not onelye to be readers, but also to be true folowers of ye gospell of our sauiour Iesu Christ, yt so we may al wt a clere conscience, come too the lordes table, banket & feaste of euerlastynge life.
div.p:
HEre ye haue (good chrystē readers) ye opinyons & sayinges of the olde faithfull fathers vpon the Sacrament of the body and bloude of Christe, compendyouslye sette forthe: Whereby ye may vnderstande and perceiue, not onelye howe we haue bene deceiued in ye matter of ye sacrament, these manye hundreth yeres, by certain false
prophetes, yet remayning here emong vs in this world, but also how we ought, if we entende to be in the vnitie of the bodye: of Christ, to come vnto this holy maundie, and banket of euerlasting saluation. Verelye, dere beloued brethren, I wold wish that all we, that do professe the gospell had alwayes when we come to this communion, that most holsome and profitable saiyng of the apostle, in our memorye and remembraunce: Purge the olde leuen, that ye maye be i. Cor, v. cha swete dowe, as ye are swete bread. For Christ our passeouer is offered vp for vs. Therefore let vs kepe holy daye, not wyth olde leauen, neyther wyth the leauen of malycyousenes & wickednes: but wt the swete bread of purenes & truth: Then shuld
all enuye, malyce and rancoure al fylthy liuing and communication, al couetousnes, fornicatiō, adultery, & abhominable whordome, all detestable swearynge strife and altercatyon be banysshed away from oure heartes. Then shuld the mouthes of the enemies of the crosse of Christe The enemyes of ye truthe, do take an occasion vpon oure naughtye lyuing, to blaspheme ye scriptures. and of his gospel, whyche vpon our wicked and filthy lyuynge, do take an occasion to speake euyl of the worde of God, and of hys moste sacred Scriptures, too the greate comforte of all godly persons, be vtterly stopped. Ye shal vnderstand, that in this place the holy apostle saint Paule doth allude to that olde sacrament of the paschal lambe; or passeouer, which ye aunciente Iues were cōmaunded to kepe in the memorial of their delyueraunce
oute of Egipte. In thys olde fygure, nothyng was commaunded so strayghtlye, as the vnleuened breade. In so muche that the lorde doth by hys prophete Moses saye. Whosoeuer Exo. xii. Cha. shall vpon these dayes eate any leuened breade, hys soule shall perisshe, frō emonge my people. This was but a figure, brethrē Mat. xvi. cha. Beware of ye leuen of ye pharises and saduces • . Cor. v. chapi Know ye not yt a litle leuen dothe sowre ye whole lumpe of dowe? of better thynges to come. For sithe that leauen in the scriptures, when it is taken in ye worse parte, doth sygnyfye bothe the hipocritical doctrin of ye vngodlye, and alsoo wycked and vnclean conditiōs wherwt ye whol man, yea the whole societie and felowshyp of mankynd is infected. It is euydente, that nowe when Christ oure true paschall lambe, is reuelated vntoo the worlde: we ought to kepe a perpetuall
passeouer, abstainyng alwaies from ye leuen of vngodly doctrine, & vnpure life. Which if we do not, with al our might and eudeuoure, sith that we do now dayly eat our true paschal lambe or passeouer, that is too saye, feade vpon the bodye and We fede dail • vpon the bod • and bloude of christ spiritually not in a mistery only, but in the reading & heringe of ye scripture. bloud of Christ spirituallye, not onely in a misterye, but alsoo in reading and hearing ye scriptures: we oughte too loke for nothing elles trulye, then for extreme damnation & death. For why? This is that roial & kinglie banket, vnto the which al nations are bidden and inuitated But if any mā doth presume to come vnto it, not hauing ye wedding raimēt or bridegromes liuery, he is by ye straighte cōmaūdement of that mightye kynge, which can kil both the soule and Mat. xxii. cha
the body, cast into vtter darkenes, where shal be wepyng and gnasshyng, of teth. Therfore yf we wil come to the lordes table He that wyll come to ye lordes table wt out ieoperdye must haue vpon hym the brydegromes liuerye. without ieopardie, if we wil receyue there an holsome repaste and not deadly poison, let vs examine truely oure selues, whether we haue that vesture, whiche is requyred of thē that are bidden to that feaste, or not. By ye lyuerie badge or cogneysaūce greate Lordes seruauntes are knowen. Heare then what the lord saith: By this shall all men Ihō. xiii. cha. Which is the brydegromes liuerye. know, that ye are my dyscyples if ye loue one an other. Hereby ye maye perceiue that loue is ye onely rayment or liuerye, without the which whosoeuer dare come to this feast, he shal be, vtterly to his own damnatyō, castawaye, as an vnprofytable and
rotten membre. For Paul saith Thoughe I hadde al fayth soo that I could moue mountains out of their own places, and yet i. Cor. xiii. cha haue noo loue, I am nothinge.

Yea, though I bestowe al my goodes too fede the poore, and gyue my bodye too be brente, & yet haue no loue, it profyteth me nothing. Surely withoute loue, we are vnprofitable & vnfruictful braunches, and be not in that knot of vnitie and peace which by thys holy sacramente is vnto vs represented. Let vs therfore caste awaye the dedes and workes of darkenes (whyche is the liuerie of our old auncyente Rom. xiii. cha The workes of darknes be the liuerye of the deuill. enemye) and put on the armour of light. Let vs walke honestly, as it were in the daye light, not in eating drynkinge neyther in chaumbring & wantonnes,
neither in strife and enuyinge: But putte we on Iesu Christ. He that doth put on Iesu Christe, as he shoulde do, or cast away the workes of darkenes, and of the flesshe, which are these: adultery, fornication, vncleannes, wantonnes, worshyppinge Gala. v. chap of idoles, witchcrafte, hatred, variaunce, wrath, strife, sedition, sectes, enuying, murder, dronkennes, glotony, and suche What hee doth put on, yt putteth on Christe Galat. v. chap like: so he doth put on, and take to him selfe: loue, peace, vnitye, concord, longe suffering, gentlenes, goodnes, faithfulnes, mekenes, temperauncye: brieflye, he doth put on all godly vertues, required of vs in the Scriptures, and worde of God. Whosoeuer is decked wyth suche a vesture and lyuerye, let hym come boldelye to the lordes supper,
and there he shall tast how swete the lorde is, there he shall receyue that lyuelye breade, yt fedeth to euerlastinge life Some wil paraduenture saye: Obiection. Thys is a straunge doctryne and contrarye to all scriptures Doth not Saincte Paule saye Roma. i. chap Gala. ii. chap that the ryghteouse shall lyue by faythe? Doth not oure iustifycatyon depende of faythe onelye? Then yf we brynge faythe to the lordes table, it is sufficyente to oure saluatyon? There shall we receiue ye most holsome phisicke yt healeth all the dyseases of the soul, and at length we shall heare ye moste comfortable word & saiing of our lord Iesus christ: go thy way, thy faith hath Mat. ix. chap Solution By faith only we are iustyfyed. Here yu must marke yt thys worde only added of ye holi doctors do not exclud good workes as thoughe whē we haue faith we shuld do nothynge, but it excludeeth ostētation and bostynge of oure good dedes. Bryeflye we muste worke, & yet saye that wee are vnprofitable seruaūtes and yt through oure workes we meryt nothinge. Gala. v. chapi Ephe. ii. chap made ye safe. I confesse & graūt & euer haue bene of ye opinion & mynd, that fayth in Iesu Christ
doth iustifye without the workes of the law. For fayth is the onely meate, wherby we apprehend the mercy of god, trust to his promises and his word. By fayth onely we are saued, oure sinnes are forgiuen, and before God we be accompted ryghtuouse, as the Apostle to the Romaines, and Galathians dothe plainly testifie. But thys faithe must be no dead faith, it must be liuely, it must worke and bringe forth fruictes worthy this our vocation and calling. For saint Paule saith: In Iesu Christ, neither is circumsion anye thinge nor yet vncircumcisiō: but faith which worketh by loue. And agayne: We are hys workemanshyp, created in Christ Iesu, vnto good workes, whyche God ordained, that we shuld walk in
them. Whych (I praye the) are those good workes? These verely are the good workes whiche The good workes yt god dothe require of vs much cōtrarye to the doctrine of Antichriste which taught ye Masses pilgrymages & such beggerly geare were good workes god hath ordained that we should walke in them al the daies of our life. To be in outward and exteryoure matters nexte vnto god, subiect vnto our kynges magistrates, and rulers to honoure father and mother, wt all trewe obedyence due vntoo them. To fede the hungrie, too geue drinke to the thirstye, too cloth the naked, to harbour the harbourles, too vysite the sicke and refresshe theym that be in pryson. Bryeflye too loue oure neyghbour as oure selues, and to do alwaies vntoo other, as we wyll be done too. These be the workes preciselye commaūded of God in hys worde and Scryptures, whiche yf we doo
not too the vttermoste of oure power, the dreadfull iudge Iesus Christe, whome wee haue despysed in hys members, shall thunder vpon vs that dreadefull and ineuytable Sentence. Marke ye thys, ye worldelynges, whych of vncharytable coueteousenesse, doo ioyne fielde to fielde, house too house, goyng aboute too be lordes and possessyoners of all the world, whensoeuer ye put anye poore man by his lyuing, thrustyng hym oute of hys house or farme, or els cause hym to paye an vnreasonable rent & income for it, therby (besides ye dearthe of all thynges, that ye cause in thys realme, through your vnsaciable auarice) bringinge him hys poore wyfe, and hys chyldren,

Howe can you nowe wyth a good, and cleare conscience, thoughe ye boste neuer soo muche of youre faythe, come to this roial feast and banket, not hauing one thrid of this wedding rayment, or bridegromes lyuery vpon you. For if ye had any sparke of loue and charitie Vnchartytablenes is cause yt the pore cōmones be so vsed. in you, ye would not so ordre the poore selye membres of Christ. Your fayth is vayne, & your knowledge is playn vanitye. For he that sayth. I knowe god and kepeth not his cōmaundementes, . i Iho. iii. he is a lyer▪ and the verytye is notte in hym. But the chyefe commaundemente, yea, the somme and effect of al
commaundementes is: Loue thy neighboure as thy own self Sith therfore that ye oppresse thus your poor neighbours, euer (as greadye horse leaches) suckyng their very bloud: yf ye say that ye knowe God, ye are but lyers, & the veritye, though ye speake neuer so godly of god and his worde, is not in you. Here I do passe ouer ye vncleanly fornication, the innumerable stinkyig adultries, and blasphemouse swearynges, the dronkenes and glotony, which reygneth emong you, which should be the lyghtes and Lanternes of all the worlde. For neyther fornycatours, neyther worshyppers of Images, nor aduouterers, nor weakelynges, nor abusers of theymselues with mankinde, nor theues,
nor coueteouse personnes nor dronkerdes, nor cursed speakers, nor extortyoners, shall enheryte the kingedome of God. Yf oure earthelye parentes shoulde threaten at anye tyme, too dysheryte vs for oure wycked and vnthryftye liuyng, we wold incontynently, rather thē we wold lose our trāsitory and corruptible patrimonie, forsake all vnthryftynes. Howe muche more oughte we, sythe that our heauenly father doth threaten, that he wyll exclud vs from his kyngdome, yf we be fornycatoures, worshyppers of Images, adulterers, coueteouse, and extortyoners, too forsake al these abhominable vices, and that by tyme, least we be put from that heuenly heritage, which Christ the sonne of the lyuynge God,
hath purchased vntoo vs, with hys precyous deathe & bloud? Verelye, as longe as suche coueteousenes, extortyon, pillyng stryfe backebytynge, adulterye and vncleane fornycation with other innumerable fylthye vyces, doo soo stronglye preuayle emonge vs, oure faythe is but a dead faythe, which the deuyll of hell hath also, and trembleth for feare. Nor we ought not, tyl Iames .ii. ch •
we haue cleane put awaye that olde leauen of vnpure lyfe, too come to the eatyng of our passeouer. For then we can not dwel in Christ, nor Chryst in vs. And yf we dwell not in Christe, nor Christ in vs, we doo notte eate hys flesshe, nor drynke hys bloude, thoughe we do a thousaunde tymes receyue the Sacramente of so high a thinge to
our vtter dampnatyon. I haue now a greate cause to lamente and bewayle in my hearte, too se the people of the lower sorte, vnto whome god of his infinite goodnes, did geue the lighte of knowledge and diuyne vnderstandinge, in so muche that many of them, whiche were neuer lerned but in theyr mother tongue, be able (thankes be vnto yt heauenly spirite) too matche, yf they goo to playne scryptures, with any doctoure of the papystes parte. I lament I say, to se howe abhomynably, the moste parte of them do lyue. Whoredome, dronkennes, and glotony vnto them is but sporte and pastime. They backbite, they sclander, they chyde and stryue. Emonge them there is no modestie, noo sobernes, no temperaūcie.
All deceyte, all crafte, all subtiltye and falsehoode, reygneth emonge theym. Whereas yf ye heare them dyspute and reason of the scriptures and worde of god, ye wil thinke that they bee very Aungels, that bene come down from heauen. So godly they talke, so godly they speake Is not this, brethren, to mocke the gospell of our sauyour Iesu Christ, the sonne of the lyuynge God? Where be nowe the wordes Math. v. cha, of our heauenly Master, & teacher become? Let your light so shine before men, yt they may se your good workes, and glorifie your father which is in heauen. Marke ye now, and printe these words in your memories and mindes. We al vnto whom the heauenly father hath reuelated his truthe, are bounde wt
our modest behauioure and honeste conuersation, to winne all men, if possible were, vntoo our master and sauiour Iesu Christ to stirre and moue theym, wyth our godly and vertuous liuing to laude and magnifye our heauenly father. Why with honest conuersation and good works? For so is the will of god, before whom, noo vncleannes, nor fylthy thing can consiste or abyde.
